question: A directional gyro indicator is basically a:

choices.choice: horizontal axis earth gyro.
horizontal axis tied gyro.
vertical axis earth gyro.
vertical axis tied gyro.

subject: Instruments

question: Apparent wander may be corrected in a DGI by:

choices.choice: causing the gyro to precess in a clockwise direction (in the northern hemisphere).
attaching a bias weight to the inner gimbal which makes the gyro precess in azimuth in the same direction as apparent wander.
correcting wander by means of air jets.
attaching a bias weight to the inner gimbal which makes the gyro precess in azimuth in the opposite direction to apparent wander.

explanation:
To counteract the effect of EARTH ROTATION WANDER, we use a LATITUDE RIDER NUT.
It imposes a precessional force on the DGI which is equal and opposite to ERW at that
latitude. This continually lines up the fixed point in space with magnetic North, effectively
making the Earth stand still.
NORTHERN HEMISPHERE : NUT SCREWED INWARDS
SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE : NUT SCREWED OUTWARDS
subject: Instruments

question: An air driven DGI is corrected for apparent wander at 56 N. If the aircraft is maintaining constant DGI readings:

choices.choice: when flying north from 56 N the true heading of the aircraft will decrease
when flying east from 56 N the true heading will decrease.
when flying south from 56 N the true heading will decrease.
when flying west from 56 N the true heading will increase.

explanation:
The DGI correction is latitude-dependent. Moving away from the latitude where the correction was applied (56°N in this case) causes inaccuracies in the DGI reading

TRANSPORT WANDER – CHANGE OF LATITUDE

  • Flight North from the ‘corrected latitude’ gives a decreasing reading (a minus drift rate).
  • Flight South from the ‘corrected latitude’ gives an increasing reading (a plus drift rate).
  • Flight away from the ‘corrected latitude’ results in the drift rate increasing.
  • Flight towards the ‘corrected latitude’ results in the drift rate decreasing.
subject: Instruments

question: The formula used to calculate apparent wander of a directional gyro in the northern hemisphere is:

choices.choice: +15 sine latitude in degrees for the time of running.
+15 sine latitude in degrees per hour.
-15 sine latitude in degrees per hour.
15 sine latitude in degrees per hour increasing

explanation:
APPARENT WANDER (DUE TO ROTATION OF THE EARTH)
The rotor axis will stay rigid in space (assuming zero real wander) while the Earth rotates under it through 360° in one day or 360/24 = 15° in one hour.

If the gyro is the DGI, its reading will be decreasing (at the North Pole) at a rate of 15°/hr. At the South Pole, the reading would increase at the same rate. This is the maximum rate of apparent wander due to the Earth’s rotation.
subject: Instruments

question: Errors of the directional gyro are:

choices.choice: acceleration error, turning error, altitude error, transport wander, rotor speed error.
gimballing error, random wander, apparent wander, rotor speed error, transport wander.
gimballing error, looping error, rolling error, rotor speed error, transport wander.
transport wander, apparent wander, latitude error, turning error, acceleration error.

explanation:
DGI ERRORS
GRAVT (Trick)

  • G: Gimballed Errors
  • R: Real/Random Wander
  • A: Apparent Wander due to Earth’s rotation
  • V: Varying RPM( rotor speed error)
  • T: Transport Error
subject: Instruments

question: The spin axis of a directional gyro is maintained in ……. by means of …… in an air driven gyro and by means of a ……. in an electrically driven gyro:

choices.choice: the horizontal plane; air jets; wedge plate.
the vertical plane; air jets; torque motor.
the yawing plane; air jets; torque motor.
the yawing plane; air jets; wedge plate.

explanation:
The jets not only spin the rotor but also serve to maintain or tie the rotor axis in the yawing plane of the aircraft.

If the aircraft banks, gyroscopic rigidity keeps the rotor axis fixed in space and it is therefore no longer in the yawing plane.

When the A/C begins to bank in a turn, the outer gimbal banks with it (since attached to the instrument case) and the rotor axis is no longer at right angles to the outer gimbal. Exhaust air now strikes one side of the wedge plane more than the other. This applies a force to the outer gimbal that is tending to rotate it about the vertical axis, which is the same as applying a force to one side of the gyro rotor. That force is precessed by the rotor to move through 90 degrees in the direction of rotation, tilting it to keep its spin axis aircraft horizontal.

ANY TENDENCY OF THE ROTOR TO MOVE FROM THE A/C HORIZONTAL REFERENCE WILL BE CORRECTED BY WEDGE PLATE DEVICE.
subject: Instruments

question: The limits of pitch and roll for a modern directional gyro are respectively:

choices.choice: 55 and 85
85 and 55
55 and 55
85 and 85

explanation: If the aircraft exceeds the pitch or roll limits of 85° (55° in air-driven gyro DGIs), the gyro will topple as the inner gimbal comes up against the stops, the precession causing the outer gimbal and scale to spin rapidly
subject: Instruments

question: Gimballing error:

choices.choice: will disappear after a turn is completed.
will remain until the gyro is reset.
will only occur during a 360 turn.
will be zero on only two headings during a 360 turn.

explanation:
GIMBAL ERROR
Occurs when gimbals of a gyroscope are not mutually perpendicular.

  • If the aircraft occurs on cardinal headings and A/C is pitched and rolled simultaneously, this error will give a false heading indication.
  • Indications will be correct once the A/C returns to straight & level flight.
subject: Instruments
